contentrichtext.text: '''Shinar''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|sh|aɪ|.|n|ɑr}};<ref>[http://www.lds.org/scriptures/bofm/pronunciation?lang=eng LDS.org: "Book of Mormon Pronunciation Guide"] (retrieved 2012-02-25), [[Wikipedia:IPA for English|IPA]]-ified from «shī´när»</ref> [[Hebrew language|Hebrew]] {{lang|he|שִׁנְעָר}} ''Šinʻar'', [[Septuagint]] Σεννααρ ''Sennaar'') is a biblical geographical locale of uncertain boundaries in [[Mesopotamia]]. The name may be a corruption of Hebrew ''Shene neharot'' ("[[Tigris–Euphrates river system|two rivers]]"), Hebrew ''Shene arim'' ("two cities"),<ref>''The New York Review'', St Joseph's Seminary, 1907, p. 205.</ref> or [[Akkadian language|Akkadian]] ''[[Sumer]]u'' (from the Sumerians' name for [[Sumer]], which meant perhaps "land of the civilized lords" or "native land"). ==Hebrew Bible== The name ''Shinar'' occurs eight times in the [[Hebrew Bible]], in which it refers to [[Babylonia]].<ref name=JewishEnc>[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=633&letter=S ''Jewish Encyclopedia'' (1906): Shinar]</ref> This location of Shinar is evident from its description as encompassing both [[Babylon]] (Babel) (in northern Babylonia) and Erech (Uruk) (in southern Babylonia).<ref name=JewishEnc/> In the ''[[Book of Genesis]]'' 10:10, the beginning of [[Nimrod]]'s kingdom is said to have been "Babel [Babylon], and [[Erech]] <nowiki>[</nowiki>[[Uruk]]<nowiki>]</nowiki>, and [[Akkadian Empire|Akkad]], and [[Calneh]], in the land of Shinar." Verse 11:2 states that Shinar enclosed the plain that became the site of the [[Tower of Babel]] after the [[Flood myth|Great Flood]]. After the Flood, the sons of [[Shem]], [[Ham (son of Noah)|Ham]], and [[Japheth]], had stayed first in the highlands of [[Armenia]], and then repaired to Shinar.<ref>Vuibert, Ancient History, 25.</ref> In ''Genesis'' 14:1,9, [[Amraphel|King Amraphel]] rules Shinar. Shinar is further mentioned in ''[[Book of Joshua|Joshua]]'' 7:21; ''[[Book of Isaiah|Isaiah]]'' 11:11; ''[[Book of Daniel|Daniel]]'' 1:2; and ''[[Book of Zechariah|Zechariah]]'' 5:11, as a general synonym for Babylonia. ==Jubilees== ''[[Jubilees]]'' 9:3 allots Shinar (or, in the Ethiopic text, ''Sadna Sena`or'') to [[Ashur]], son of [[Shem]]. ''Jubilees'' 10:20 states that the [[Tower of Babel]] was built with [[bitumen]] from the sea of Shinar. [[David Rohl]] theorized that the Tower was actually located in [[Eridu]], which was once located on the Persian Gulf, where there are ruins of a massive, ancient [[ziggurat]] worked from bitumen.<ref>Rohl, David, ''Legends: The Genesis of Civilization'' (1998) and ''The Lost Testament'' (2002)</ref> ==Other possible attestations== Sayce identified ''Shinar'' as cognate with the following names: ''Sangara''/''Sangar'' mentioned in the context of the Asiatic conquests of [[Thutmose III]] (15th century BCE); ''Sanhar''/''Sankhar'' of the [[Amarna letters]] (14th century BCE); the Greeks's ''[[Singara]]''; and modern ''[[Sinjar]]'', in [[Upper Mesopotamia]], near the [[Khabur River]].<ref name=JewishEnc/><ref name=Sayce>Sayce, Archibald Henry (1895). ''[http://books.google.com/books?id=Png-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA67 Patriarchal Palestine]'', pp. 67-68.</ref> Accordingly, he proposed that Shinar was in Upper Mesopotamia, but acknowledged that the Bible gives important evidence that it was in the south.<ref name=Sayce/> ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Mesopotamia]] [[Category:Sumer]] [[Category:Torah places]]
